bioghist.p: Frank Hartman (1893-1986), was a radium specialist and consultant, and owner of Radium Services, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 1919-1956. He started selling radium products after World War I. In 1934 he became a sales agent for radium from the Eldorado Mining and Refining Company of Canada, which along with the Atomic Energy Commission after World War II, supplied him with radium and various isotopes. By the late 1930s, Hartman was acutely aware of the dangers of radium and took it upon himself to locate and recover pieces lost by area hospitals and industry until his retirements in 1956.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Frank Hartman. Materials include: correspondence with academic institutions, officials of government and cancer societies, and Philadelphia radiologists, relating to Hartman's services; reports, catalogs, and price lists, including US Atomic Energy publications (1918-1960s) of radium products; photographs; a diary of radium retrieval efforts (1930s-1956); clippings regarding radium in Philadelphia area (1930s-1960s); reprints, flyers in German and English for radiation therapies (1920s-1930s); books on radium and radioactivity (1904-1968); photographs of Marie Curie, Frank Hartman, and Hartman Laboratories; and other papers relating to Hartman's life and career. The collection also includes: 117 glass lantern slides related to radium, radioactivity, and the Curies; framed photos and illustrations of radiation theory and phenomena; a binder of photos made from glass slides and box of other photos; publications relating to the radiation industry, including Vols. 14 and 17 of Atomic Energy of Canada, Ltd. Published Papers; and 2 cassettes (and CDs) of 1971 and 1976 interviews with Hartman.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
